div.p: The electron–phonon coupling in fullerene C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} has been calculated from first principles. The value of the associated coupling constant λ/N⁢(0)𝜆𝑁0italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda/N(0) is found to be a factor three larger than that associated with C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}. Assuming similar values of the density of levels at the Fermi surface N(0) and of the Coulomb pseudopotential μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*} for C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}–based solids as those associated with alkali doped fullerides A33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, one obtains Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28})≈RELOP:approximately-equals\approx8Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60})

The valence properties of small fullerenes [1], in particular of the smallest fullerene yet observed C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}, is a fascinating question at the fundamental level as well as in terms of its potential applications for the synthesis of new materials [2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. In supersonic cluster beams obtained from laser vaporization, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} is the smallest even-numbered cluster, and thus the fullerene displaying the largest curvature, which is formed with special abundance. In fact, under suitable conditions, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} is almost as abundant as C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} [3]. At variance with its most famous family member C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} is expected to form a covalent crystal (like C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} [8, 9, 10]), and not a Van der Waals solid [11]. However, similarly to C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, fullerene C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}maintains most of its intrinsic characteristics when placed inside an infinite crystalline lattice [2]. The transport properties of the associated metal doped fullerides, in particular superconductivity, can thus be calculated in terms of the electron–phonon coupling strength λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda of the isolated molecule, and of the density of states of the solid [12, 13]. In keeping with the fact that curvature–induced hybridization of the graphite sheet π𝜋italic-pi\pi orbitals, seems to be the mechanism explaining (cf. [12, 13, 14, 15] and refs. therein) the large increase in Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} in going from graphite intercalated compounds (Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}≈5absent5RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5\approx 5K) [16] to alkali–doped C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} fullerides, (Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}≈30-40absent3040RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:30 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:40\approx 30-40K) [17, 18, 19], fullerene C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} is a promising candidate with which to form a high–Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} material. These observations call for an accurate, first–principle investigation of the electronic and vibrational properties, as well as of the electron–phonon coupling strength of this system. In the present work we present the results of such a study, carried out within ab–initio density functional theory (DFT) in the local spin density approximation (LSDA). Our findings are that the associated value of λ/N⁢(0)𝜆𝑁0italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda/N(0) is a factor 2.52.5NUMBER:2.52.5 and 1.21.2NUMBER:1.21.2 larger than that associated with C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} [13] and C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} [9] respectively. Under similar assumptions for the density of levels at the Fermi energy N(0) and for the Coulomb pseudopotential μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*} as those associated with alkali-doped fullerides A33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, one will thus expect Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28})≈RELOP:approximately-equals\approx8Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}), opening the possibility for C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}–based fullerides which are superconducting at, or close to, room temperature.

The equilibrium geometry of C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} obtained in the present calculation is similar to that proposed by Kroto and co–workers [20], and has the full Td𝑑FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{d} point group symmetry. All atoms are three fold coordinated, arranged in 12 pentagons and 4 hexagons. The large ratio of pentagons to hexagons makes the orbital hybridization in C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} more of sp33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} type rather than sp22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}, the typical bonding of graphite and C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}. The sp33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3}–like hybridization is responsible for a series of remarkable properties displayed by small fullerenes in general and by C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} in particular. Some of these properties are : a) the presence of dangling bonds, which renders C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} a strongly reactive molecule, b) the fact that C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} can be effectively stabilized (becoming a closed shell system displaying a large HOMO–LUMO energy gap) by passivating the four tetrahedral vertices either from the outside (C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4}) or from the inside (U@C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}) [3]. It also displays a number of hidden valences: in fact, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H1010FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:10 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{10}, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H1616FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:16 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{16}, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H2222FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:22 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{22} and C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} are essentially as stable as C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}H44FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:4 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{4} (all displaying HOMO–LUMO energy gap of the order of 1.51.5NUMBER:1.51.5 eV) [1], in keeping with the validity of the free–electron picture of π𝜋italic-pi\pi–electrons which includes, as a particular case, the tetravalent chemist picture, c) while typical values of the matrix elements of the deformation potential involving the LUMO state range between 10–100 meV, the large number of phonons which couple to the LUMO state produces a total electron–phonon matrix element of the order of 1 eV (cf. Table 1), as large as the Coulomb repulsion between two electrons in C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}. This result (remember that the corresponding electron–phonon matrix element is ∼0.1similar-toabsent0.1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1\sim 0.1 eV and the typical Coulomb repulsion is ∼0.5-1similar-toabsent0.51RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1\sim 0.5-1 eV for C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} [13]) testifies to the fact that one should expect unusual properties for both the normal and the superconducting state of C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}–based fullerides, where the criticisms leveled off against standard theories of high Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} of fullerenes (cf. e.g. refs. [13, 21, 22, 23, 24] and refs. therein) will be much in place.

In Fig 1(a), we report the electronic structure of C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} ccomputed within the Local Spin Density approximation, as obtained from a Car–Parrinello [25] molecular dynamics scheme [26, 27]. Near the Fermi level we find three electrons in a t2subscript𝑡2italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{2} orbital, and one in a a1subscript𝑎1italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:enda_{1} orbital, all with the same spin, in agreement with the results of [3]. The situation is not altered, aside from a slight removal of the degeneracy, when the negative anion, C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}-FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{-}, is considered (see Fig. 1(b)). In this case, the additional electron goes into the t2subscript𝑡2italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:endt_{2} state, and has a spin opposite to that of the four valence electrons of neutral C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}.

The wavenumbers, symmetries, and zero-point amplitudes of the phonons of C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} are displayed in Table 1, together with the matrix elements of the deformation potential defining the electron–phonon coupling with the LUMO state. The total matrix element summed over all phonons is equal to 710710NUMBER:710710 meV. The partial electron–phonon coupling constants λα/N⁢(0)subscript𝜆𝛼𝑁0italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda_{\alpha}/N(0), also shown in Table 1, sum up to 214214NUMBER:214214 meV. This value is a factor 2.52.5NUMBER:2.52.5 larger than that observed in C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} [13], and a factor 1.21.2NUMBER:1.21.2 larger than the value recently predicted for C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} [9]. In Fig. 2 we display the values of λ/N⁢(0)𝜆𝑁0italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda/N(0) for C7070FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:70 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{70}, C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} and C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} [9, 30, 31, 32], which testify to the central role the sp33FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{3} curvature induced hybridization has in boosting the strength with which electrons couple to phonons in fullerenes [12, 13, 14, 15].

In keeping with the simple estimates of Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} carried out in refs. [13, 9] for C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} and C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} based solids, we transform the value of λ/N⁢(0)𝜆𝑁0italic-lambda MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda/N(0) of Table 1 into a critical temperature by making use of McMillan’s solution of Eliashberg equations [33, 34]

semantics.annotation: italic-T POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end ARG:start NUMBER:1.2 ARG:end OPFUNCTION:exponential OPEN:[ ADDOP:minus FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start NUMBER:1.04 OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-lambda CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start italic-lambda ADDOP:minus italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus NUMBER:0.62 italic-lambda CLOSE:) ARG:end CLOSE:] PUNCT:,

div.p: where ωl⁢nsubscript𝜔𝑙𝑛italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{ln} is a typical phonon frequency (logarithmic average), λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda is the electron–phonon coupling and μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*} is the Coulomb pseudopotential, describing the effects of the repulsive Coulomb interaction. Typical values of ωl⁢nsubscript𝜔𝑙𝑛italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\omega_{ln} for the fullerenes under discussion is ωl⁢n≈103subscript𝜔𝑙𝑛superscript103italic-omega POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-l italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\omega_{ln}\approx 10^{3}K (cf. e.g. [35, 36]). Values of N(0) obtained from nuclear magnetic resonance lead to values of 7.27.2NUMBER:7.27.2 and 8.18.1NUMBER:8.18.1 states/eV–spin for K33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} and Rb33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, respectively (cf. ref. [13] and refs. therein). Similar values for N(0) are expected for C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36} [9]. Making use of these values of N(0) for all Cn𝑛FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{n}–based solids (n𝑛italic-nn=70,60,36 and 28), one obtains 0.2≤λ≤30.2𝜆3NUMBER:0.2 RELOP:less-than-or-equals italic-lambda RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:30.2\leq\lambda\leq 3 for the range of values of the associated parameter λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda. The other parameter entering Eq. (1), namely μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*} and which is as important as λ𝜆italic-lambda\lambda in determining Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} is not accurately known. For C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*} is estimated to be ≈0.25absent0.25RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.25\approx 0.25 [13]. Using this value of μ*superscript𝜇italic-mu POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\mu^{*}, and choosing N(0) so that Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}≈19.5absent19.5RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:19.5\approx 19.5K for C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}, as experimentally observed for K33FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{3}C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60} [13], one obtains Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28})≈RELOP:approximately-equals\approx8Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C6060FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:60 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{60}) and Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28})≈RELOP:approximately-equals\approx1.3Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}(C3636FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:36 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{36}) [37].

We conclude that C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28}–fullerene displays such large electron–phonon coupling matrix elements as compared to the repulsion between two electrons in the same molecule, that it qualifies as a particular promising high Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} superconductor. From this vantage point of view one can only speculate concerning the transport properties which a conductor constructed making use of C2020FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{20} [40] as a building block can display. In fact, this molecule is made entirely out of 12 pentagons with no hexagons, being the smallest fullerene which can exist according to Euler theorem for polyhedra, and thus displaying the largest curvature a carbon cage can have.
Calculations have been performed on the T3E Cray computer at CINECA, Bologna.

K. Tanigaki, T.W. Ebbesen, S. Saito, J. Mizuki, J.S. Tsai, Y. Kubo and S. Kuroshima, Nature 352 (1991) 222.
T.T.M. Palstra, O. Zhou, Y. Iwasa, P.E. Sulewski, R.M. Fleming and B.R. Zegarski, Solid State Commun. 93 (1995) 327.
T.T.M. Palstra, A.F. Hebard, R.C. Haddon and P.B. Littlewood, Phys. Rev. B 50 (1994) 3462.
H. Kroto, Nature 329 (1987) 529.
P. Anderson, Theories of fullerens Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c}’s which will not work, August 20, 1991 (unpublished).
L. Pietronero and S. Strässler, Europhys. Lett. 18 (1992) 627.
L. Pietronero, S. Strässler and G. Grimaldi Phys. Rev. B 52 (1995) 10516.
C. Grimaldi, L. Pietronero and S. Strässler, Phys. Rev. B 52 (1995) 10530.
R. Car and M. Parrinello, Phys. Rev. Lett. 55 (1985) 2471.
J. Hutter et al., MPI Für Festkörperforschung, Stuttgart, and IBM research, 1990–1997. The code has been partially modified to calculate the matrix elements of the deformation potential.

The whole calculation (i.e., geometry optimization of the cluster, Kohn-Sham levels, phonons and deformation potential) has been carried out by setting C2828FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:28 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{28} in a fcc supercell of 26 a.u. A norm-conserving Trouiller-Martins [28, 29] pseudopotential has been employed in the calculation, with a cutoff of 40 Ry.
N. Troullier and J.L. Martins, Phys. Rev. B 43 (1991) 1993.
M. Fuchs, M. Scheffler, Comput. Phys. Commun. 119 (1999) 67.
D. Provasi, N. Breda, R.A. Broglia, G Colò, H.E. Roman and G. Onida, Phys. Rev. B (in press).
O. Gunnarsson, Phys Rev. B 51 (1995) 3493.
N. Breda, R.A. Broglia, G. Colò, H.E. Roman, F. Alasia, G. Onida, V. Ponomarev and E. Vigezzi, Chem. Phys. Lett. 286 (1998) 350.
W.C. McMillan, Phys. Rev. 167 (1968) 331.
G.M. Eliashberg, Soviet Phys.–JETP 696 (1960) 896.
D.S. Bethune, G. Meijer, W.C. Tang, H.J. Rosen, W.G. Golden, H. Seki, C.A. Brown and M.S. de Vries, Chem. Phys. Lett. 179 (1991) 181.
Z.H. Wang, M.S. Dresselhaus, G. Dresselhaus and P.C. Eklund, Phys. Rev. B 48 (1993) 1681.
Similar values of Tc𝑐FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{c} are obtained using Allen’s solution [38, 39] of Eliashberg equations.
P.B. Allen, R.C. Dynes, Phys. Rev. B 12 (1975) 905.
P.B. Allen and B. Mitrovič, Solid State Physics, edited by H. Ehrenreich, F. Seitz, and D. Turnbull, vol. 37, (Academic press, New York, 1982), p. 1.

While no clear evidences have been found in carbon cluster beams for a particularly abundant bare C2020FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{20} cluster, the fully hydrogenated C2020FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{20}H2020FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:20 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{20} molecule, dodecahedrane, turns out to be stable [41].
L.A. Paquette, R.J. Ternansky, D.W. Balogh, G.J. Kentgen, J. Am. Chem. Soc. 105 (1983) 5446.

In columns 4 and 5 the corresponding electron–phonon matrix elements gαsubscript𝑔𝛼italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:endg_{\alpha} and partial coupling constants λα/N⁢(0)subscript𝜆𝛼𝑁0italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-alpha POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-N OPEN:( NUMBER:0 CLOSE:)\lambda_{\alpha}/N(0) are displayed. In the last row we show the corresponding summed values.
